The fundus exam demonstrates a blunted foveal reflex and a grayish discoloration in the parafoveal area with fine yellow-white intra-retinal spots.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What is the most notable abnormality in the fundus photograph?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
An intravenous fluorescein angiogram was obtained next:

![](/content/media/retina-22-2.webp)

Pattern of IVFA consistent with perifoveal hyper-fluoresence (leakage pattern). Next, an OCT macula was performed as shown below:

![](/content/media/retina-22-3.webp)

What layers of the retina are involved in this pathological process as shown in the OCT?

answers.answerText: A. Inner Nuclear Layer and Inner Plexiform Layer ONLY
B. Bruch's Membrane and RPE with outer retinal cysts
C. Outer Nuclear Layer and Ellipsoid Zone with inner retinal cysts
answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-22-4.webp)

There are hypo-reflective cavities involving the inner retina with an overlying ILM (draping of ILM). There are focal areas of loss in the outer retinal layers, with disruption of the IS/OS junction.

answers.answerText: D. Ganglion cell layer and External Limiting Membrane

title: Case 22
description: 56M presenting with suspected diabetic macular edema
patientPresentation:
A 56-year-old male was referred to clinic for suspected diabetic macular edema. His past ocular history was unremarkable, and his past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes that is controlled by diet only. He is otherwise healthy. On exam, vision is 20/50 OD, and 20/20 OS. Pupils were equal and reactive, with no relative afferent pupillary defect and IOP was 15mmHg in both eyes. Slit lamp examination was normal.
